The meaning of the phrase 'right in two' is straight from the bible: 1 kings 3 16-28:

King Solomon, the wisest man to ever live is holding court.

The case is that of a child, and two women claim to be the mother, each saying that the child of the other died in the night, and her own live child was stolen.

The king said bring a sword, and orders that the living child be 'cut in two', and half be given to each woman.

The real mom immediately gives up her claim, willing to give up her child rather than see it killed. Fake mom says, sure, this seems a fair settlement. Solomon then correctly awards custody to the rightful mother.

We silly monkeys are like fake Mom, fighting to the bitter end, willing to divide things in two, destroying them in the process, in the interest of 'fairness', but without regard for the end result.

This seems a departure for Tool, using the bible with out sarcasm, but the song is about human nature, not biblical truth. In this case, the story from the bible happens to fit perfectly.

Conscious of his fleeting time here."

One of the natural inclinations of human beings since we have been human beings is to ask the BIG questions... Why am I here? What is the Purpose of Life? etc...

Our existences are like fire. We spark into existence and burn for a short time then extinguish. There is, cosmically speaking, a very miniscule amount of time involved in the span of even the longest-lived human being's lifetime. And yet, we squander it.

Knowing our inherent mortality, we should be able to understand the fleeting nature of our own lifetime. 

To understand our imminent mortality and yet practice willful ignorance as to our origin, destination and purpose; to not even begin the long and arduous journey toward understanding and enlightnment (a path on which MJK and likely the rest of TOOL have well advanced) is to live in a primitive and lowly state of existence, like uncivilized and blissfully ignorant "talking monkeys."

It took me some time to read all the interesting variety of posts here, and I must say it was most amusing.
I find it interesting the amount of disagreement and the level of emotion, which has sprung from a simple posting of song lyrics, and the resulting open forum discussion.

It is when one becomes embroiled in the disagreement, challenged by anotherâs perspective, that one decides they must take a hard line stand on an issue that, given time to rationally analyze, they may otherwise come to the same conclusion as the person they are squaring off against.

This is an interesting Tool song, as it seems to be very religiously inspired, namely by the God and angels of the Christian faith. 

In the first verse, it's talking about angels wondering why God (God is often referred to as 'Father' or 'The Father' in the Bible) gave humans free will, as that has a lot of potential for disaster. 

In the second verse, the angels point out that even though Eden is a perfect place, the humans will never be satisfied and still make the wrong decision (Adam and Eve eating the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil).

Third verse: The angels lament the fact that even though God created humans to be rational and logical, they choose the wrong thing.

In the 'Monkey killing monkey' verse, it's stated that humans are no better than the monkeys (perhaps a theory of evolution reference), and that they misuse gifts that have great potential for good, instead making weapons ('Give them thumbs...')

In verses 6 and 8, the angels say that humans ignore the important things (in this case, Heaven, salvation, etc.) and instead focus on greedy things of the earth and killing for them; which, when compared to Heaven, is meaningless. 

Verse 9 restates how the virtues of reason and patience are put aside in conflict. 

I believe the phrase 'Cutting it right in two' could be about: Even when something is truth/right/good/just (an absolute singularity), humans can disagree or take sides on it (cutting it in two). 

To conclude, I believe Tool is asking how a good God could give humans free will, though that's a self-defeating question. However, Right in Two is still a well-written and sobering message on the depravity of man.
